title: 106_s783
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Guelff Body Armor Act of 2000". It includes findings related to body armor. Congress finds that police officers and citizens face increased danger from criminals using deadly weaponry and body armor. Crime is worsened by the interstate movement of body armor. There is a traffic in body armor affecting interstate commerce, and existing Federal controls are inadequate. Recent incidents, such as the murder of Officer James Guelff and a 1997 bank shootout in California, highlight the need for regulation. The serious threat posed by criminals wearing body armor during violent crimes is highlighted in California. Statistics show that a significant number of officers killed in the line of duty could have been saved by body armor. The Department of Justice estimates that 25 percent of State and local police do not have access to body armor. Congress has the power to grant local police departments access to surplus body armor from Federal agencies. The Constitution allows Congress to regulate interstate commerce for community safety. The Constitution allows Congress to regulate interstate commerce for community safety. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "body armor" refers to protective gear against gunfire, "law enforcement agency" is an authorized agency for law enforcement, and "law enforcement officer" includes officers at various levels of government. Authorized entities in States or political subdivisions can engage in criminal law activities as per government regulations. The Federal sentencing guidelines will be amended to increase the offense level by at least 2 levels for any offense involving the use of body armor. This enhancement will not apply to offenses related to civil rights violations by law enforcement officers. Additionally, there is a prohibition on the purchase, use, or possession of body armor by violent felons. The definition of body armor is expanded to include any product intended to protect against gunfire. A new prohibition is introduced, making it illegal for violent felons to purchase, own, or possess body armor. The new prohibition makes it illegal for violent felons to purchase, own, or possess body armor unless they have prior written certification from their employer stating it is necessary for lawful business activity. The term 'employer' in this subsection refers to any individual supervising the defendant's business activity. If the defendant has no supervisor, written certification from any other employee of the business is acceptable. Section 931 prohibits violent felons from purchasing, owning, or possessing body armor. Violating this section can result in a fine, imprisonment for up to 3 years, or both. Additionally, Section 6 allows for the donation of federal surplus body armor to state and local law enforcement agencies. The Federal agency can donate surplus body armor to State or local law enforcement agencies if it is in serviceable condition. The donation must be reported to the Administrator of General Services. Certain officers, like those in the Department of Justice, can also make donations. The Department of Justice can designate certain officers to act as the head of a Federal agency, including the Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration, the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Commissioner of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, and the Director of the United States Marshals Service. The Department of the Treasury can also designate officers to administer this section. The Secretary of the Treasury can designate certain officers to act as the head of a Federal agency, including the Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms, the Commissioner of Customs, and the Director of the United States Secret Service. The United States is not liable for any harm related to the use of donated body armor. Passed the Senate on October 25, 2000. Attest: GARY SISCO, Secretary.
